In Khartoum, the faces of a martyred capital: 'War cannot kill ideas, nor love'
subhead: War in Sudan: A Trapped Nation (3/6). Le Monde's reporters traveled through the Sudanese capital, which for two years was the epicenter of the conflict. They met with residents, who recounted how they survived despite fear and violence.

Several femicides mark the end of 2025 in France
subhead: A man was taken in for questioning on January 1 after police discovered his partner's body in their yard in Nantes (western France). In Lille (north), two femicide cases cast a shadow over the year-end holidays, reflecting a rise in the number of women killed by their partners or ex-partners.

title: Ban on social media for under-15s: What we know about the government's plan
subhead: In addition to banning smartphones in high schools, a new law aims to block the youngest from accessing social media platforms. President Emmanuel Macron mentioned the topic during his New Year's address, and Parliament will debate the measure at the start of the year.

title: At the Louvre, tension builds over creation of new 'Mona Lisa' gallery
subhead: The Louvre-Nouvelle Renaissance architecture competition aims to create a room for Leonardo da Vinci's iconic painting and a new entrance for the Paris museum, which has seen a surge in visitors. Five teams have been shortlisted, none of which are French.

title: They cook organic, distrust science and oppose vaccines: America's 'crunchy moms' shift toward Trump
subhead: In the 1960s, the 'crunchy mom' was typically an American hippie trying to stay connected to nature. Today, she claims total freedom over health decisions, sometimes flirting with conspiracy theories.

Early Christian fresco depicting Jesus as the Good Shepherd discovered in Turkey
subhead: One month after Pope Leo XIV's visit, Turkish authorities announced the discovery in Iznik, Anatolia, of a depiction of Christ in a well-preserved burial chamber.

title: Bulgaria joins the euro divided, in political crisis and without a budget
subhead: The Balkan country adopted the European single currency on January 1, but the population remains unenthusiastic. The country only has a caretaker government and corruption is endemic.

title: Physical activity can reduce the risk of death: 'It's very hard to find a drug that can do that'
subhead: Longevity physician Peter Attia highlights in his book the importance of physical exercise to combat what he calls the 'four horsemen': cardiovascular disease, cancer, dementia, and metabolic disorders.
